Yes, this makes sense. Before Darwin these guys were called naturalists, not scientists. Therefore they never utilized the "scientific method" that was around for centuries. This way they had to shoe-horn everything into their prethought out system. So that penguins, ostriches, ducks and eagles are all "birds" despite that fact that some fly, some don't, some swim on the water, some under the water, and some survive at sub-zero temperatures. But they all evolved from a common ancestor that no one has ever found.

Nothing against peasants, but Lamarck wasn't one. He was the eleventh child of a relatively poor but aristocratic family from Picardy. Toffs in pre-Revolutionary France had incredibly long names, and Lamarck's full name was in fact Jean-Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet, Chevalier de Lamarck.

HANK YOU NEED TO LEARN ABOUT THE ANTEPENULT RULE! For most technical words (especially those that come from greek) the emphasis goes on the third to last syllable. Seriously man, if you just listen to this ONE TINY RULE you'll stop making almost all of your pronunciation mistakes. (eg it's MicROScopists, not MicroSCOPEists). Seriously, look back at every mispronunciation you've done in this series. Almost all of them would be solved by you putting the emphasis on the third to last syllable rather than just 'wherever'.

Bonus information:
Linnaeus tried to do binomial nomenclature because the English bible mentions living things as "kinds". So, he started by finding out where the lines lie separating kind from kind. He soon found out that life is far more complex than that and used more levels of classification to categorize it. If I remember correctly, he ended up with 6 levels, and more were added after his death. Of course even that is far too simplistic to classify all of life. Serious biologists now use cladistics.
